content.description:
Climb right up the middle of the right side of the back wall.  Start standing with your right hand on a pinch and your left on a crimp with a good left food.  Go up to a large, juggy ledge in the middle of the wall and made a committing mantle/press up onto and off of it to reach the top of the wall straight up.  Bring an extra pad and a friend - falling on this committing crux move would put you back-first onto an exceptionally point boulder.



The back wall has two sides and a clear break in the middle.  If you're facing the Glass Slab, look to your left.  This route climbs up the middle of the right (if you're facing it) side of the back face.

The fall isn't bad except for the very pointy detached block behind it.  You'll go straight down, except on the committing last mantle move, and if you fail and don't have extra pads and a spotter for this you will be mildly impaled.

Start with both hands on the edge just to the right of the vertical seam, and one foot on an edge closer to the ground.



Toward the eastern end of the East Side field, and back toward the cliff (i.e., moving away from the road).

GPS: 62.511963, -113.693983 

Clean fall.

Climb the bleached white and orange (right/west) side of the last face of any height at the east side of the field.  Start seated with your right hand on a pinch, your left pushing off any edge you can make use of to the left, and a high right foot.  Move up through large ledges and blocks to the top.  Avoid the edge of the boulder to the right.



At the bottom/ground level at the foot of the boulder field.  Near the east end of it.

Clean fall

climbs.name: The Easter Bunny Lays an Egg

content.description:
Climb the blocky face at the far right end of the back wall.  Start on a waist-height ledge and work up through big features to top out.  Easy, but good moves through good holds.



At the right end of the back wall, there is an off width crack that separates the wall from a mostly detached block that is bulbous and vaguely egg-shaped.  This is the face around the corner/to the right of this crack.

Clean fall

Like climbing a polished, featureless sheet of glass.  A friction slab with almost no real means of generating friction.

Climb the left side of the glassy face, avoiding all features on the Glass Menagerie to your right if you can reach them (it's a decent quarter pad crimp to the right).  2-3 difficult slab moves on polished, nearly invisible feet gain you a quarter pad crimp to stabilize on before bumping to the top.  As of writing, it is Yellowknife's hardest slab.  However, its shortness makes it very height-dependent.  Tall people who can reach the crimp right away won't find much of a challenge, while short people might have 3-4 moves on the barely-there feet.



Towards the top of the hill, there is an angled boulder falling away from the face at the back of the area.  It's towards the left/east side of the area.  The climbable face is on the back/facing the back wall.

Short but awkward fall.

Climb the right side of the face along the faint arete-like feature.  Rounded, smooth little edges and two quarter-pad crimps will get you to the top.



Towards the top of the hill, there is an angled boulder falling away from the face at the back of the area.  It's towards the left/east side of the area.  The climbable face is on the back/facing the back wall.

Short but slightly awkward fall.

Start in a crouch with your hands in the crack, right foot on the rock at the bottom of the crack and left foot on a nice edge. Go up and over the face, keeping your body out of the crack.



Near the beginning of the East Side field, if walking east from the Right Across the Road field.

GPS: 62.511688, -113.694938

Clean fall.
The second boulder field across the road from the parking lot.  It's just a bit further down the road, but you can see it clearly from the parking lot.
